Title: Linking forum posts -casebiostat-01-T1.1
Description: The workers will be presented with posts from a forum thread where instructors of a course have replied to student posts. The worker is required to: identify the student post(s) that the instructor’s reply addresses. Instructor's reply post is highlighted
Keywords: tagging, categorization, discussion forum, forum threads, mooc
Input.posts:
I would take the comment that the function of the median of a random variable is the same as the median of the function of the random variable given that the function is one to one. Might be the case for continuous random variables but not for discrete ones. Although in practical applications this may not be an issue it would not necessarily be the case. For example, let's say that outcomes 1,2,3,4,5 occur with equal probability and some function maps those to 10, 9, 2, 7, 8 respectively. The median of the original random variable is 3, which maps to 2, which is not the median of the function of the original random variable. This is a very arbitrary example, of course.

Now, it does happen that pooled estimates are more precise (less variable) than stratum specific estimates because for the pooled estimates you have a larger sample size. This is because the standard error of the estimator (the mean in this case) decreases as the sample size increases. Best, Francis
